sec.title: Meaning of the Pledge of Allegiance
sec.p: A pledge is a promise to do something. Allegiance means being loyal to something. When people say the Pledge of Allegiance, they stand in front of the American flag. They promise to be loyal to the United States of America. This means that they will support the ideas of the country.

People from other countries who become United States citizens say the Pledge of Allegiance when they become new U.S. citizens. Many students say the Pledge at the start of the school day in their classrooms. People often say it at the beginning of sports events, too.
When people say the Pledge of Allegiance, they put their right hand over their heart. Then they say the words.

sec.title: Words of the Pledge of Allegiance
sec.p: The Pledge of Allegiance was written in 1892. Some words changed over the years. These are the words of the Pledge of Allegiance today:

preformat.italic:
I pledge allegiance to the flag of the United States of America
and to the Republic for which it stands, one nation under God,
indivisible, with liberty and justice for all.

sec.title: History
sec.p: The Pledge of Allegiance was first written in 1892. It was printed in a magazine called The Youth's Companion. The words were a little different from the words Americans say today.

In 1942, leaders in the United States approved the Pledge of Allegiance. At that time, the Pledge did not include the words "under God." In 1954, President Dwight Eisenhower asked leaders to approve a law or rule adding these words. The law also included instructions about how people should say the Pledge of Allegiance.

sec.title: No One Is Forced to Say the Pledge of Allegiance
sec.p: Some Americans choose not to say the Pledge of Allegiance. That is their right, or freedom.

The Supreme Court of the United States said that people cannot be forced to say the Pledge of Allegiance. The Supreme Court is the highest court in the United States. It makes important decisions about American laws.
